results.title: And then there was glass
results.brief_description: This documentary shows how glass is made. It gives an impression of the modern (1969) automatic machinery producing the molten material which is to be blown or pressed into the required shapes. It also shows the varied types of glass, and the uses to which they are put.
results.description: This documentary shows how glass is made. It gives an impression of the modern (1969) automatic machinery producing the molten material which is to be blown or pressed into the required shapes. It also shows the varied types of glass, and the uses to which they are put.

results.title: And their ghosts may be heard
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Caroline Jones and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In 1893 a boat load of Australian bush workers and tradesmen sailed halfway around the world to Paraguay to establish a New Australia colony in which the old Australian principles of equality and mateship would at last be realised. The film follows the footsteps of those pioneers from a strike-torn sheep country into the heart of Paraguay, landlocked into the heart of South America, where the survivors of the great experiment still live today, dreaming in exile of the gum trees in a far-off land their ancestors chose to leave but could never forget. Presented by Caroline Jones and sourced from the book by Gavin Souter “A Peculiar people: the Australians in Paraguay”. English/Spanish language.

results.title: And spare the child
results.creator_credit: Antonio Colacino, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Raises the problem of when and how to discipline children. Every culture has certain standards or values, and children absorb attitudes and values from the family. Discusses the role that discipline has to play in this process and how this discipline should change as the child grows and develops.

results.title: And so ends
results.creator_credit: Dick Young and Dick Young Productions
results.brief_description: Uses the recollection of octogenarian Robert Cushman Murphy to provide a historical view of whaling and to present a plea for the preservation of the whale. The more recent footage shows the sophistication of modern whaling techniques and notes the years 1960-1970 represented the greatest decade of over whaling in terms of numbers killed. Narrated by Jack Palance. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: And now Miguel
results.creator_credit: Joseph Krumgold and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: A portrait of an American family to whom the tradition of sheep raising has come down through generations of Spanish ancestors. It is the story of family unity, and of young Miguel and the fulfillment of his dream of being accepted on an equal footing by his father and brothers.

results.title: And he will rise again
results.brief_description: Easter in the modern world. The meaning of Easter is the manifold sacrifice of God and Man in the person of Jesus, atoning for the sins of mankind. Unfortunately this meaning escapes many younger Australians. Both the passion of Christ and the meaning of Easter contrast the nonchalant reality of the young people, who drift throught the Easter weekend without a thought for its ‘sacred’ significance and its application to their relatively empty lives. Written by Peter Tammer, camera by Tom Cowan and organ by Harold Fabrikant.

results.title: Ancient Tashkent: an impression
results.brief_description: For a relatively short time Tashkent was a great market city on the spice route from China to Europe. This lyrical non-narrative film draws in viewers to experience for themselves the richness of its mosaics and the grandeur of its architecture. Makes imaginitive use of authentic Uzbek music.

results.title: Ancient Rome
results.brief_description: As a city, religious centre, and capital of an empire, Ancient Rome dominated the people of its times. The achievements of Rome in government, architecture, engineering, and law are summarized, and our own inheritances from Roman culture established.

results.title: Ancient Persia
results.brief_description: Magnificent ruins now reveal the history of the great Empire of Cyprus and Darius, the splendid palaces of Persepolis, great roads, and gold coinage. Famous sites like Marathan, Hellespont, Thermopylae, and the Bay of Salamis, indicate the shift of power to the Greeks, and the end of the Persian domination.

results.title: Ancient Mesopotamia
results.creator_credit: John Smart and Coronet Instructional Films
results.brief_description: The contributions of the Sumerians, Semites, Babylonians and Assyrians who occupied the Tigris-Euphrates Valley are depicted against authentic locales that include Babylon, Ur and Nineveh. These people were first to use the arch and the wheel. They developed a code of laws, a system of writing and military science - all of which have become a part of Western civilization. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
